longitudinal_wave.title: Longitudinal Wave
longitudinal_wave.goal: Explore how waves like sound travel.

centrifugal_force.title: Centrifugal Force
centrifugal_force.concept: Centrifugal force is the feeling of being pushed outwards when you're spinning or moving in a circle. Think about being on a merry-go-round; the force that feels like it's pulling you away from the center is centrifugal force. It's actually the result of inertia—your body's desire to keep going in a straight line, but the ride is turning you in a circle. The faster you spin, the stronger this feeling becomes!
centrifugal_force.goal: Spin the bucket and see the effect of centrifugal force.

quiz.question: What happens if you spin the bucket faster?

momentum.title: Momentum
momentum.concept: Momentum measures how hard it is to stop a moving object. It's the product of mass and velocity (p = m * v).
momentum.goal: See how mass and speed affect collisions and learn conservation of momentum with simple colliding carts.

quiz.question: If a heavy truck and a light car move at the same speed, which has more momentum?

conservation_of_energy.title: Conservation of Energy
conservation_of_energy.concept: Energy can't be created or destroyed, it just changes from one form to another. Think of it like a superhero who can change costumes—it's still the same hero, just in a different outfit! This is one of the most important rules in all of science.
conservation_of_energy.goal: Transform energy from one form to another and see how it flows.

quiz.question: When a light bulb is on, electrical energy is changed into...

electricity.title: Static Electricity
electricity.concept: Static electricity is all about the tiny particles called electrons. When you rub two things together, sometimes electrons jump from one to the other. The one that gains electrons becomes negatively charged, and the one that loses them becomes positively charged. Just like magnets, opposite charges attract, and like charges repel!
electricity.goal: Choose the charge for the second particle and see if it attracts or repels the first one.

quiz.question: If two balloons both have a negative charge, they will...

electric_circuits.title: Electric Circuits
electric_circuits.concept: An electric circuit is a closed path that allows electric current to flow. Circuits contain sources (like batteries), conductors (wires), and loads (like bulbs or resistors).
electric_circuits.goal: Build simple series and parallel circuits and observe how current and voltage behave.

quiz.question: In a simple series circuit with two identical bulbs, if one bulb is removed, what happens to the other bulb?

electromagnetism.title: Electromagnetic Spectrum Sort
electromagnetism.concept: Electromagnetism is a fundamental force of nature that describes the interaction between electrically charged particles. This interaction is mediated by electromagnetic fields, which include both electric and magnetic fields.
electromagnetism.goal: Sort the different types of electromagnetic radiation from lowest to highest energy.

quiz.question: Which of these has the longest wavelength?

newtons_laws_of_motion.title: Newton's Laws of Motion
newtons_laws_of_motion.goal: Explore the fundamental laws of motion.

energy.title: Energy
energy.goal: Explore the ability to do work.

atoms.title: Atoms
atoms.definition: Atoms are the tiny, fundamental building blocks of everything!
atoms.example: A single drop of water contains billions of water molecules.

quiz.question: What are the main particles inside an atom?

states_of_matter.title: States of Matter
states_of_matter.definition: Matter usually exists in three states: solid, liquid, or gas.

quiz.question: An ice cream cone in the sun turns from a solid into a...?

chemical_reactions.title: Chemical Reactions
chemical_reactions.definition: A chemical reaction transforms substances into new ones.
chemical_reactions.example: Baking a cake is a chemical reaction.

quiz.question: What happens when you mix baking soda and vinegar?
options: It fizzes and creates a gas
quiz.answer: It fizzes and creates a gas

periodic_table.title: Periodic Table
periodic_table.definition: The periodic table organizes all known chemical elements by increasing atomic number and recurring chemical properties.
periodic_table.example: Hydrogen (H) is the simplest element and is at the top-left of the table.

quiz.question: Which element has the atomic number 1?

cells.title: Cells
cells.definition: Cells are the basic building blocks of all living things.
cells.example: Your body is made of trillions of cells!

quiz.question: What is the 'brain' of the cell called?

photosynthesis.title: Photosynthesis
photosynthesis.definition: Plants use sunlight to create their own food.
photosynthesis.example: A sunflower turns its face to the sun to get energy.

quiz.question: What do plants release that is essential for humans?

ecosystems.title: Ecosystems
ecosystems.definition: An ecosystem is a community of living things interacting with their environment.
ecosystems.example: A coral reef is a vibrant ecosystem.

quiz.question: Which of these is NOT an ecosystem?

dna.title: DNA
dna.definition: DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) carries the genetic instructions used in growth, development, functioning, and reproduction of organisms.
dna.example: DNA makes each individual unique — it's why siblings can look different.

solar_system.title: The Solar System
solar_system.definition: Our solar system is made up of the Sun and the planets that orbit it.
solar_system.example: Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system.

quiz.question: Which planet is famous for its beautiful rings?

stars.title: Stars
stars.definition: Stars are giant, luminous balls of hot gas. Our Sun is a star!
stars.example: At night, we see thousands of stars from Earth.

quiz.question: What is the name of our closest star?

galaxies.title: Galaxies
galaxies.definition: A galaxy is a huge collection of stars. We live in the Milky Way galaxy.
galaxies.example: The Andromeda Galaxy is the nearest major galaxy to our own.

quiz.question: What is the name of the galaxy we live in?
